questions.text:
A 72-year-old woman presents to the office with a 6-month history of neck pain and back pain. She is a passionate gardener, but her pain has been preventing her from doing any gardening work that requires looking up or bending down. Review of records reveals hypertension. Results of a recent routine DEXA scan show a T-score of -3.5, consistent with severe postmenopausal osteoporosis. Medications are metoprolol, calcium, and vitamin D supplements. Physical examination reveals:

No localized neurologic deficits
OA flexed, rotated left, sidebent right
Anterior cervical tender point at C5 on the left
Increased paraspinal muscle tension at T4–T6 on the left
L2 extended, rotated right, sidebent right
Anterior innominate rotation on the right

The most appropriate osteopathic manipulative technique for this patient is

choices.text: compression of the fourth ventricle
muscle energy
counterstrain
high-velocity low-amplitude
direct myofascial release

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Compression of the fourth ventricle (CV4) is an osteopathic cranial manipulative technique used to influence the flow of cerebrospinal fluid and improve the cranial rhythmic impulse. This technique is used for certain cranial conditions (e.g., sphenobasilar synchondrosis compression), which typically manifest with cranial symptoms (e.g., headaches, tinnitus, and vertigo), none of which are seen in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Muscle energy is an active and usually direct technique that utilizes voluntary muscle contraction against a controlled counterforce applied by the physician. Indications include somatic dysfunction, muscle shortening, joint restriction, and muscle spasm. In patients with severe osteoporosis, the technique's inherent direct stress on the bones can precipitate fractures. A different, more gentle treatment is more appropriate for this patient.

C) CORRECT:

Counterstrain is a passive indirect technique, i.e., the tissue is moved away from the restricted barrier. It is used to treat somatic dysfunctions associated with tender points and is especially suitable for patients with osteoporosis. In this patient, the neck would be gently positioned into the most comfortable and least painful position for 90 seconds to alleviate pain from the cervical tender point.

Due to the risk of fracture in patients with severe osteoporosis, the application of direct techniques requires extreme caution. Specifically, high-velocity low-amplitude (HVLA) maneuvers are contraindicated in patients at risk of fracture. Other contraindications for HVLA include metastatic bone disease, osteomyelitis, severe disk herniation with radiculopathy, and joint instability (e.g., of the cervical spine in patients with rheumatoid arthritis or Down syndrome).

D) INCORRECT:

High-velocity low-amplitude (HVLA) is a passive direct technique that utilizes a rapid and short force to restore motion or alignment. Indications include joint restrictions, locked facet joints, or restricted motion. Severe osteoporosis is an absolute contraindication for HVLA because of the high risk of fractures caused by forceful motion.

E) INCORRECT:

Direct myofascial release involves moving tissues toward the restrictive barrier and applying manual pressure to fascial restrictions. Indications include hypertonic muscles, fascial strains, and myofascial adhesions. In patients with severe osteoporosis, the direct force applied when performing this technique can precipitate fractures. A different, more gentle treatment is more appropriate for this patient.
questions.hint: This patient, who has severe postemenopausal osteoporosis, is at increased risk of fracture.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man presents to the office with a 5-day history of upper back pain and chest pain. Three days ago, he visited the emergency department, and cardiac evaluation showed no abnormalities. One month ago, he was diagnosed with gastroesophageal reflux disease and started PPI therapy. He denies any trauma but says that he lifted heavy boxes last week. Vital signs reveal:


Blood pressure
134/82 mm Hg


Heart rate
82/min


Respiratory rate
12/min


Physical examination reveals:

Normal heart sounds
Lungs clear to auscultation
Soft abdomen with mild epigastric tenderness

Tender point on the sternum at the level of the attachment of rib 3 

Which of the following is the most appropriate counterstrain treatment position?

choices.text: Flexion with sidebending and rotation away from the tender point
Flexion with sidebending toward and rotation away from the tender point
Flexion without sidebending or rotation
Extension with sidebending and rotation away from the tender point
Extension with sidebending away from and rotation toward the tender point

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Flexion with sidebending and rotation away from the tender point is the appropriate counterstrain position for treating a tender point located at anterior lumbar level 5 (AL5); it is not appropriate for treating anterior thoracic tender points. A useful mnemonic for treating an AL5 tender point is F SARA: flexed, sidebent away, and rotated away.

B) INCORRECT:

Flexion with sidebending toward and rotation away from the tender point is the appropriate counterstrain position for treating tender points at anterior thoracic levels 7–12 (AT7–AT12); it is not appropriate for treating an AT3 tender point. A useful mnemonic for treating AT7–AT12 tender points is F STRA: flexed, sidebent toward, and rotated away.

C) CORRECT:

Treating somatic dysfunctions with counterstrain involves positioning the patient to shorten the muscle where the tender point is located, thereby reducing the muscle spindle's activity and restoring normal length. Pure flexion in a supine position shortens the anterior chest muscles and reduces tension at anterior thoracic tender points levels 1–6 (AT1–AT6).
Image Description:

AT1: midline, below the sternal notch

AT2: midline, level of T2

AT3: midline, level of T3

AT4: midline, level of T4

AT5: midline, level of T5

AT6: midline, level of T6

AT7: midline, xiphoid process; midclavicular line, level of 7th intercostal space

AT8: midline, level of T12; midclavicular line, level of T12

AT9: midline, above umbilicus, level of L2; midclavicular line, above the umbilicus

AT10: midline, below the umbilicus, level of L4; midclavicular line, below the umbilicus

AT11: midline, level of L5; midclavicular line, level of sacral base

AT12: midclavicular line, just inside the iliac crest superior to the anterior superior iliac spine

D) INCORRECT:

Extension with sidebending and rotation away from the tender point is the appropriate counterstrain position for tender points located at the posterior thoracic levels (PT1–PT12) on the spinous processes; it is not appropriate for treating anterior thoracic tender points. A useful mnemonic for treating PT1–PT12 tender points on the spinous processes is E SARA: extended, sidebent away, and rotated away.

E) INCORRECT:

Extension with sidebending away from and rotation toward the tender point is the appropriate counterstrain position for tender points located at the posterior thoracic levels (PT1–PT12) on the transverse processes; it is not appropriate for treating anterior thoracic tender points. A useful mnemonic for treating PT1–PT12 tender points on the transverse processes is E SART: extended, sidebent away, and rotated toward.
questions.hint: This patient has an anterior thoracic tender point located on the midline and corresponding to the level of rib 3 (i.e., AT3).

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presents to the office with a 1-month history of low back pain. The pain is dull, localized to the paraspinal area of the lower back, and exacerbated by prolonged standing and forward bending. She denies any trauma, numbness, or weakness. Past medical history is unremarkable. Muscle strength, tone, and reflexes are normal in the lower extremities. Sensation is intact. A straight leg raise elicits moderate lumbar pain without any radicular symptoms. Structural examination reveals restricted lumbar flexion, pain that is reproduced at end range, and an anterior tender point for L5 on the left. This patient's tender point is most likely located on the

choices.text: lateral aspect of the anterior inferior iliac spine
medial aspect of the anterior inferior iliac spine
inferior aspect of the anterior inferior iliac spine
anterior-superior aspect of pubic ramus
medial aspect of the anterior superior iliac spine

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The anterior L3 (AL3) tender point is located on the lateral aspect of the anterior inferior iliac spine.

B) INCORRECT:

The anterior L2 (AL2) tender point is located on the medial aspect of the anterior inferior iliac spine.

C) INCORRECT:

The anterior L4 (AL4) tender point is located on the inferior aspect of the anterior inferior iliac spine.

D) CORRECT:

The anterior L5 (AL5) tender point is located approximately 1 cm lateral to the pubic symphysis on the anterior-superior surface of the pubic ramus.

Tender points are small, localized, hyperirritable spots within muscles or tendons, often presenting as swollen or edematous areas that are notably painful upon palpation. Unlike trigger points, stimulation of tender points does not cause referred pain.
Image Description:

AL1 (internal oblique): medial to the anterior superior iliac spine

AL2 (external oblique): medial to the anterior inferior iliac spine

AL3 (iliopsoas): lateral to the anterior inferior iliac spine

AL4 (iliopsoas): inferior to the anterior inferior iliac spine

AL5 (rectus abdominis): anterior surface of the pubis

E) INCORRECT:

The anterior L1 (AL1) tender point is located on the medial aspect of the anterior superior iliac spine.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presents to the office with a 1-month history of low back pain. The pain is dull, localized to the paraspinal area of the lower back, and exacerbated by prolonged standing and forward bending. She denies any trauma, numbness, or weakness. Past medical history is unremarkable. Muscle strength, tone, and reflexes are normal in the lower extremities. Sensation is intact. A straight leg raise elicits moderate lumbar pain without any radicular symptoms. Structural examination reveals restricted lumbar flexion, pain that is reproduced at end range, and an anterior tender point for L5 on the left. To treat with counterstrain, which of the following treatment positions is most appropriate?

choices.text: Hip flexed with right sidebending and left rotation
Hip extended with right sidebending and right rotation
Hip flexed with left sidebending and right rotation
Hip flexed with right sidebending and right rotation

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Flexion, sidebending away, and rotation towards the tender point is the appropriate counterstrain position for anterior tender points L2–L4 rather than AL5. A useful mnemonic for remembering the correct treatment for the anterior L2–L4 tender points is F SART: flexion, sidebending away, and rotation toward.

B) INCORRECT:

Extension, sidebending away, and rotation away from the tender point is the appropriate counterstrain position for posterior tender points L1-L5 rather than anterior L5 tender point. Extension is used for pain relief in patients with posterior lumbar tender points, but it is not used for anterior lumbar tender points. A useful mnemonic for remembering the correct treatment for the posterior L1-L5 tender points is E SARA: extension, sidebending toward, and rotation away.

C) INCORRECT:

Flexion, sidebending toward, and rotation away from the tender point is the appropriate counterstrain position for anterior tender points L1 rather than AL5. A useful mnemonic for remembering the correct treatment for the anterior L1 tender points is F STRA: flexion, sidebending toward, and rotation away.

D) CORRECT:

Counterstrain is used to relieve pain by placing the body in a position of ease to alleviate the tension and strain of the affected structures. When treating an anterior lumbar tender point for L5 (AL5) with counterstrain, you position the hip in flexion with sidebending and rotation away from the tender point. Therefore, for a left AL5 tender point, hip flexion, sidebending to the right, and rotation to the right are performed. A useful mnemonic for remembering the correct treatment for AL5 tender point is F SARA: flexion, sidebending away, and rotation away.

AL1 is treated with F STRA (i.e., flexion, sidebending toward, rotation away) and AL2–4 are treated with F SART (i.e., flexion, sidebending away, rotation toward). See “Anterior lumbar tender points” table.
questions.hint: Counterstrain is a passive, indirect technique in which the affected tissue being treated is positioned away from the restrictive barrier.

questions.text: A 29-year-old man presents to the office with a 5-day history of sharp pain in his right mid-back that started after heavy lifting training at the gym. Past medical history reveals Crohn disease. On examination, a posterior tender point is noted on the costal angle of rib 5 on the right. The patient rates the pain as 8/10 on a tenderness scale. Rib 5 on the right moves well with inhalation but descends poorly with exhalation. To treat with counterstrain, which of the following patient positions is most appropriate?

choices.text: extension, sidebending away from, and rotation toward tender point
flexion, sidebending toward, and rotation away from tender point
flexion, sidebending and rotation away from tender point
flexion, sidebending and rotation toward tender point
extension, sidebending and rotation away from the tender point

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Extension, sidebending away from, and rotation toward tender point is the appropriate counterstrain position for a posterior tender point on rib 1 (PR1). A useful mnemonic for remembering the correct treatment for a PR1 is E SART: extended, sidebent away, and rotated toward.

B) INCORRECT:

Flexion, sidebending toward, and rotation away from tender point is the appropriate counterstrain position for anterior thoracic tender points AT7–AT12. A useful mnemonic for remembering the correct treatment for AT7–AT12 is F STRA: flexed, sidebent toward, and rotated away.

C) CORRECT:

A seated position with the neck and upper torso minimally flexed and sidebent and rotated away from the tender point is the appropriate counterstrain position for treating posterior rib tender points 2–10 (PR2–PR10).This position should be adjusted until tenderness is reduced by at least 70% and then held for two minutes. Finally, the physician returns the body to a neutral position while the patient remains passive. Posterior rib tender points are often associated with an inhalation rib dysfunction.

A useful mnemonic for remembering the correct treatment for PR2–PR10 is F SARA: flexed, sidebent away, and rotated away. Note that for a posterior tender point on rib 1 (PR1), the treatment position differs (E SART: extended, sidebent away, and rotated toward the tender point). See “Overview of posterior rib tender points” table.
Image Description:

PR1–PR12: posterior rib angle of each named point

D) INCORRECT:

Flexion, sidebending and rotation toward tender point is the appropriate counterstrain position for treating anterior rib tender points 1–10 (AR1–AR10). A useful mnemonic for remembering the correct treatment for AR1–AR10 is F STRT: flexed, sidebent toward, and rotated toward. Anterior rib tender points are typically associated with exhalation rib dysfunction.

E) INCORRECT:

Extension, sidebending and rotation away from the tender point is the appropriate counterstrain position for posterior thoracic tender points PT1–PT12 that are located on the spinous process. A useful mnemonic for remembering the correct treatment for PT1–PT12 (spinous process) is E SARA: extended, sidebent away, and rotated away.
questions.hint: This patient presents with a posterior tender point on rib 5 (PR5) and an inhalation rib dysfunction. Tender points are typically treated with counterstrain, a passive, indirect technique in which the patient is placed in a pain-free position.

questions.text: A 49-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a 4-day history of left-sided neck pain. She recalls sleeping in an uncomfortable position and believes her pillow was not properly supporting her neck. She currently rates the pain as 5 on a scale of 0 to 10. She denies any trauma, radicular pain, or numbness. Examination reveals an anterior tender point located on the lateral aspect of the transverse process of C4 on the left side. The most appropriate counterstrain treatment position for this patient's tender point is

choices.text: flexion with sidebending to the right and rotation to the right
extension with sidebending to the right and rotation to the left
extension with sidebending to the left and rotation to the left
extension with sidebending to the right and rotation to the right
flexion with sidebending to the left and rotation to the right
flexion with sidebending to the left and rotation to the left

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

To treat with counterstrain, the patient's neck should be placed in a position that alleviates the tension and strain of the affected structures. When treating anterior cervical tender points AC2–AC6, flexion of the neck shortens and relaxes the affected muscles. Additionally, sidebending away and rotating away from the side of the tender point are employed to reduce tenderness. Therefore, for a left-sided AC4 tender point, flexion with sidebending to the right and rotation to the right are performed. A useful mnemonic for remembering the correct treatment for AC2–AC6 and AC8 is F SARA: flexion with sidebending away and rotating away.

AC1 is treated with rotation away (RA) from the tender point without sidebending, flexion, or extension. AC7 is treated with flexion, sidebending toward and rotation away (F STRA). See “Anterior cervical tender points” table.
Image Description:

AC1: high on the posterior edge of the mandibular ramus between the earlobe and angle of the mandible

AC2–AC6: anterolateral tip of the anterior tubercle of each named transverse process

AC7: superior surface of the clavicle (clavicular attachment of the sternocleidomastoid)

AC8: medial head of the clavicle (sternal attachment of the sternocleidomastoid)

B) INCORRECT:

Extension with sidebending away from and rotation toward the tender point (E SART) is the appropriate counterstrain position for tender points located at the posterior thoracic levels (PT1–PT12) on the transverse processes; it is not appropriate for treating cervical tender points.

C) INCORRECT:

Extension would further stretch already sensitive anterior muscle fibers around the tender point, which could lead to more pain. Moreover, sidebending and rotating towards the tender point would further tense and exacerbate the strain on the involved musculature.

D) INCORRECT:

Extension with sidebending and rotation away from the tender point (E SARA) is the appropriate counterstrain position for certain posterior cervical tender points (e.g., PC3–PC7 lateral); it is not appropriate for treating anterior cervical tender points.

E) INCORRECT:

Flexion with sidebending toward and rotation away from the tender point (F STRA) is the appropriate counterstrain position for AC7; it is not appropriate for treating other anterior cervical tender points.

F) INCORRECT:

Flexion with sidebending to the left and rotation to the left is the appropriate counterstrain position for AC4 on the right (not left) side.
questions.hint: The anterior cervical tender point 4 (AC4) is located on the anterolateral tip of the transverse process of the C4 vertebra. To alleviate pain, the affected muscle should be shortened.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman presents to the office with a 10-day history of sharp neck pain. She denies any numbness, tingling, or trauma but mentions that she recently installed curtains, which required her to repeatedly look upward for over an hour. Past medical history reveals hypercholesterolemia, which is managed with atorvastatin. A tender point is found at the superior surface of the left clavicle near the attachment of the sternocleidomastoid muscle. The most appropriate counterstrain treatment positioning is

choices.text: flexion with sidebending to the left and rotation to the right
rotation to the right only
flexion with sidebending to the right and rotation to the left
extension with sidebending to the right and rotation to the right
flexion with sidebending to the right and rotation to the right

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Most anterior cervical tender points are treated with flexion, sidebending away, and rotation away (F SARA) from the tender point. However, AC1 and AC7 are exceptions because pain does not resolve using the SARA position. To treat an AC7 tender point, the neck should be flexed, sidebent toward, and rotated away (F STRA) from the tender point. Therefore, the most appropriate counterstrain treatment position for the left AC7 is flexed, sidebent to the left, and rotated to the right.

See “Overview of anterior cervical tender points” table.
Image Description:

AC1: high on the posterior edge of the mandibular ramus between the earlobe and angle of the mandible

AC2–AC6: anterolateral tip of the anterior tubercle of each named transverse process

AC7: superior surface of the clavicle (clavicular attachment of the sternocleidomastoid)

AC8: medial head of the clavicle (sternal attachment of the sternocleidomastoid)

B) INCORRECT:

Rotation away from the tender point (without flexion, extension, or sidebending) is the appropriate counterstrain treatment position for the AC1 tender point.

C) INCORRECT:

Flexion with sidebending to the right and rotation to the left is the appropriate counterstrain position for AC7 on the right rather than the left side.

D) INCORRECT:

Extension with sidebending and rotation away from the tender point (E SARA) is the appropriate counterstrain treatment position for most posterior rather than anterior cervical tender points.

E) INCORRECT:

Flexion with sidebending and rotation away from the tender point (F SARA) is the appropriate counterstrain position for AC2–AC6 and AC8 tender points.
questions.hint: The superior surface of the clavicle at the level of C7 corresponds to anterior cervical tender point 7 (AC7).

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman presents to the office with a 2-month history of right buttock pain radiating to her posterior thigh. She works as a sales manager in a call center and mentions that she has to take a break to stretch every hour because of the pain. Family history reveals osteoporosis in her mother. She is 158 cm tall (5 ft 2 in) and weighs 75 kg (165 lb); BMI is 30 kg/m2. On physical examination, a tender point is noted on the patient's right side between the lateral edge of the sacrum and the greater trochanter. The patient consents to receiving osteopathic manipulative treatment. The most appropriate counterstrain treatment position for this patient's tender point is

choices.text: prone, hip flexed, abducted, and externally rotated
supine, hip flexed and externally rotated
prone, hip extended and adducted
supine, hip flexed and externally rotated, lumbar sidebending to the right
prone, hip extended, abducted, and externally rotated

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient presents with a piriformis tender point (a posterior pelvic tender point) and should first be placed in the prone position. Then, ipsilateral hip and knee flexion, abduction, and external rotation are employed to shorten and relax the piriformis muscle. To reduce tenderness and pain, maintain this position for 90 seconds so the proprioceptive firing decreases, and then slowly return the leg to the neutral position. A piriformis tender point may be found in the setting of piriformis syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

A supine position with flexion and external rotation of the hip is appropriate for counterstrain of the iliacus tender point, which is an anterior pelvic tender point located one-third of the distance between the anterior superior iliac spine and the midline. This patient presents with piriformis muscle involvement, which suggests a posterior pelvic tender point.

C) INCORRECT:

A prone position with extension of the hip and adduction of the ipsilateral lower extremity is appropriate for counterstrain of posterior lumbar tender points. Adduction of the lower extremity sidebends and rotates the spine away from the tender point. Tenderness would be located along the transverse processes of L1–L5 or the inferior/inferolateral aspect of any spinous process of L1–L5.

D) INCORRECT:

A supine position with hip flexion and external rotation of the hip, together with sidebending toward the dysfunction is appropriate for counterstrain of the psoas tender point, which is an anterior pelvic tender point located two-thirds of the distance between the anterior superior iliac spine and midline. This patient presents with a piriformis muscle involvement, suggesting a posterior pelvic tender point.

E) INCORRECT:

A prone position with extension, abduction, and external rotation of the hip is appropriate for counterstrain of a high ilium sacroiliac tender point, which is a posterior pelvic tender point. Tenderness would be located approximately 3 cm lateral to the posterior superior iliac spine.
questions.hint: Tender points between the lateral edge of the sacrum and the greater trochanter together with sciatica (i.e., pain that radiates to the posterior thigh) indicate piriformis muscle involvement.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents to the office with a 5-day history of neck pain. He recalls that his discomfort began after he had to change all of the light bulbs from the chandeliers in his house. He reports no radiation of the pain and denies any trauma. He has atrial fibrillation and his only medication is metoprolol. Physical examination reveals a tender point at the right inferior aspect of the spinous process at C2. Neurologic examination shows no abnormalities. To treat with counterstrain, this patient's neck should be positioned in

choices.text: flexion only
extension with sidebending and rotation to the left
extension with sidebending to the left and rotation to the right
flexion with sidebending and rotation to the left
flexion with sidebending to the right and rotation to the left

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pure flexion (without sidebending or rotation) is the appropriate counterstrain position for the PC1 midline tender point, which is located at the inferior nuchal line near the inion.

B) INCORRECT:

Extension with sidebending and rotation away from the tender point (E SARA) is the appropriate position for treating most posterior cervical tender points, but not the PC3 midline tender point.

C) INCORRECT:

Extension with sidebending away and rotation toward the tender point (E SART) is the appropriate position for treating the posterior rib tender point PR1, not cervical tender points.

D) CORRECT:

Most of the posterior cervical tender points are treated with extension, sidebending away, and rotation away from the tender point (E SARA) because this position shortens the muscles and has been shown to alleviate tension and strain. However, PC1 midline and PC3 midline tender points are exceptions as they do not resolve with muscle shortening; for PC3 midline, the neck should be flexed, sidebent and rotated away (F SARA) from the tender point. Therefore, the counterstrain position for the right PC3 midline tender point is flexion with sidebending and rotation to the left.

See “Overview of posterior cervical tender points” table.
Image Description:

PC1 inion (midline): inferior nuchal line, lateral to the inion

PC1 occiput (lateral): just below the nuchal line, midway between the inion and mastoid process

PC2 occiput (lateral): inferior nuchal line at the attachment of the semispinalis capitis

PC2 (midline): superior aspect of the C2 spinous process

PC3–PC7 (midline): inferior aspect of the spinous process of the vertebra above the named point

PC3–PC7 (lateral): posterior-lateral surface of articular processes of each named point

PC8 (midline): inferior aspect of C7 spinous process

E) INCORRECT:

Flexion with sidebending towards and rotation away from the tender point (F STRA) is the appropriate counterstrain position for the anterior cervical tender point AC7, which is located anteriorly at the superior surface of the clavicle.
questions.hint: Tenderness to palpation at the inferior-lateral aspect of the C2 spinous process is consistent with the posterior C3 midline tender point (PC3 midline), which does not follow the general rules of counterstrain.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a 2-month history of intermittent right lower abdominal pain that increases after prolonged sitting. She denies any recent trauma but mentions that she has been doing more core-strengthening exercises lately. Vital signs are within normal limits. Abdominal examination shows no abnormalities. Musculoskeletal examination reveals a tender point at one-third of the distance between the anterior superior iliac spine and the midline. She rates the pain as a 6 on a scale of 0 to 10; the pain does not radiate. The patient consents to treatment with counterstrain. The most appropriate positioning to treat this patient is

choices.text: supine with the hip flexed and externally rotated
prone with the hip extended, abducted, and externally rotated
prone with the hip flexed, abducted, and externally rotated
prone with the hip extended and adducted
supine with the hip flexed, adducted, and internally rotated

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The iliacus tender point is an anterior pelvic tender point that can cause pain in the groin area and/or anterior hip pain and is aggravated by prolonged periods of sitting. To treat with counterstrain, the patient should be placed in the supine position while the physician stands on the side of the tender point. Then, the physician flexes and externally rotates the hips. This position is maintained for 90 seconds to decrease propioceptive firing. The leg is then returned to the neutral position.

See “Overview of anterior pelvic tender points” table.
Image Description:

Psoas major: two-thirds between anterior superior iliac spine and midline

Iliacus: one-third between the anterior superior iliac spine and the midline

Low ilium (psoas minor): anterior-superior aspect of the pubic ramus ∼ 2 inches lateral to the pubic symphysis

Inguinal: superior pubis near the medial end of the inguinal ligament

Low ilium flare-out: inferior-medial surface of the descending ramus of the pubic bone

B) INCORRECT:

A prone position with the hip extended, abducted, and externally rotated is the appropriate counterstrain position for the quadratus lumborum tender point, which is a posterior lumbar tender point located at the inferior aspect of the 12th rib and the superior aspect of the iliac crest.

C) INCORRECT:

A prone position with the hip flexed, abducted, and externally rotated is the appropriate counterstrain position for piriformis tender points, which are posterior pelvic tender points located between the lateral edge of the sacrum and the greater trochanter (within the belly of the piriformis muscle).

D) INCORRECT:

A prone position with the hip extended and adducted results in sidebending and rotation at the spinal level away from the tender point, which is the appropriate counterstrain position for posterior lumbar tender points PL1–PL5. The tender points may be located on the inferolateral aspect of the spinous processes of L1–L5 or the lateral aspect of the transverse processes of L1–L5.

E) INCORRECT:

A supine position with the hip flexed, adducted, and internally rotated is appropriate for the treatment of the pectineus or inguinal tender point, which is an anterior pelvic tender point located at the superior pubis near the medial end of the inguinal ligament. The technique is typically performed with both knees and hips brought into flexion. The contralateral leg is then crossed over the ipsilateral leg (i.e., the side of the tender point) and the ipsilateral hip is adducted and pushed into internal rotation.
questions.hint: This patient presents with a right iliacus tender point, which is located one-third of the distance between the anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS) and the midline.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents to the office requesting osteopathic manipulative treatment for right-sided rib pain. The pain is sharp and exacerbated by deep inhalation and coughing. On questioning, the patient denies any trauma. Medical history is significant for bronchitis 3 weeks ago. Vital signs are normal. Physical examination shows normal heart and lung findings. There is a tender point located at the right 7th rib on the anterior axillary line. Ribs 6–8 on the right move poorly with inhalation. The most appropriate counterstrain treatment position is

choices.text: flexion with left sidebending and left rotation
extension with left sidebending and right rotation
extension with left sidebending and left rotation
flexion with right sidebending and left rotation
flexion with right sidebending and right rotation

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Flexion with sidebending and rotation away from the tender point is the appropriate counterstrain position for treating tender points at posterior ribs 2–10 (PR2–PR10). A useful mnemonic for remembering the correct treatment position for PR2–PR10 tender points is F SARA: flexed, sidebent away, and rotated away.

B) INCORRECT:

Extension with sidebending away from and rotation toward the tender point is the appropriate counterstrain position for treating a tender point at posterior rib 1 (PR1). A useful mnemonic for remembering the correct treatment position for a PR1 tender point is E SART: extended, sidebent away, and rotated toward.

C) INCORRECT:

Extension with sidebending and rotation away from the tender point is the appropriate counterstrain position for treating posterior thoracic tender points PT1–PT12 that are located on the spinous processes. A useful mnemonic for remembering the correct treatment position for PT1–PT12 tender points on the spinous processes is E SARA: extended, sidebent away, and rotated away.

D) INCORRECT:

Flexion with sidebending toward and rotation away from the tender point is the appropriate counterstrain position for treating anterior thoracic tender points AT7–AT12. A useful mnemonic for remembering the correct treatment position for AT7–AT12 tender points is F STRA: flexed, sidebent toward, and rotated away.

E) CORRECT:

Flexion with sidebending and rotation toward the tender point is the appropriate counterstrain position for treating all tender points at anterior ribs 1–10 (AR1–AR10). This position should be adjusted until tenderness is reduced by at least 70% and then held for two minutes. Finally, the physician returns the patient to a neutral position. A useful mnemonic for remembering the correct treatment position for treating AR1–AR10 tender points is F STRT: flexed, sidebent toward, and rotated toward.

See “Overview of anterior rib tender points” table.
questions.hint: Exhalation rib dysfunctions are typically associated with anterior rib tender points, whereas inhalation rib dysfunctions are usually related to posterior rib tender points.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents to the office with a 1-week history of right-sided neck pain and stiffness. The pain is dull and localized to the cervical area. He currently rates the pain as a 4 on a scale of 0 to 10. The patient reports that the pain began after spending several hours working on his laptop. He denies any trauma, radicular pain, or numbness. On examination, a tender point is identified on the right side of the posterior aspect of C5, slightly lateral to the articular process. The most appropriate counterstrain treatment positioning is

choices.text: flexion only
flexion with sidebending and rotation to the left
flexion with sidebending to the right and rotation to the left
extension with sidebending and rotation to the left
rotation to the left only

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pure flexion (without sidebending or rotation) is the appropriate counterstrain position for the PC1 midline tender point, which is located at the inferior nuchal line near the inion.

B) INCORRECT:

Flexion, sidebending away, and rotation away from the tender point (F SARA) is the appropriate counterstrain position for most anterior cervical tender points (except AC1 and AC7) and the PC3 midline tender point.

C) INCORRECT:

Flexion with sidebending toward and rotation away from the tender point (F STRA) is the appropriate counterstrain position for anterior cervical tender point AC7, which is located at the superior surface of the clavicle.

D) CORRECT:

To treat with counterstrain, the patient's neck should be placed in a position that alleviates the tension and strain of the affected structures. When treating posterior cervical tender points PC3–PC7 lateral, extension shortens and relaxes the posterior cervical muscles. Additionally, sidebending away and rotating away from the side of the tender point are employed to reduce tenderness. Therefore, extension, sidebending to the left, and rotation to the left is performed for a right PC5 tender point. A useful mnemonic for remembering the correct treatment for posterior cervical tender points (except for maverick points PC1 midline and PC3 midline) is E SARA: extension with sidebending away and rotation away from the tender point. PC1 midline is treated with pure flexion and PC3 midline is treated with flexion, sidebending away, and rotation away (F SARA).

See the “Overview of posterior cervical tender points” table.
Image Description:

PC1 inion (midline): inferior nuchal line, lateral to the inion

PC1 occiput (lateral): just below the nuchal line, midway between the inion and mastoid process

PC2 occiput (lateral): inferior nuchal line at the attachment of the semispinalis capitis

PC2 (midline): superior aspect of the C2 spinous process

PC3–PC7 (midline): inferior aspect of the spinous process of the vertebra above the named point

PC3–PC7 (lateral): posterior-lateral surface of articular processes of each named point

PC8 (midline): inferior aspect of C7 spinous process

E) INCORRECT:

Rotation away from the tender point (without flexion, extension, or sidebending) is the appropriate counterstrain treatment position for the AC1 tender point, which is located between the earlobe and the angle of the mandible near the transverse process of C1.
questions.hint: The posterior C5 (PC5) lateral tender point is located at the posterolateral aspect of the articular process of the C5 vertebra.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes to the office because of 4 months of upper back pain. The pain is localized to the right paraspinal area and exacerbated with prolonged sitting. He denies any trauma, numbness, or weakness. Past medical history is unremarkable. He works as a security guard. Muscle strength, tone, and reflexes in the upper extremities are normal bilaterally. Sensation is intact. Physical examination reveals restricted back flexion and a tender point located on the T4 transverse process on the right. The patient agrees to receive osteopathic manipulative treatment. Which of the following positions is most appropriate to treat with counterstrain?

choices.text: Extended torso, sidebent left, rotated right
Flexed torso, sidebent right, rotated left
Flexed torso, sidebent left, rotated left
Extended torso, sidebent left, rotated left
Flexed torso, sidebent right, rotated right

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Counterstrain is a passive indirect technique used to relieve pain by positioning the affected area away from the restrictive barrier (i.e., into a position of ease), thus shortening the affected muscle. When treating posterior thoracic tender points PT1–PT12 on the transverse processes, the patient is positioned with their torso extended, sidebent away, and rotated toward the tender point (E SART).

See the “Overview of posterior thoracic tender points” table.
Image Description:

PT1–PT12: the spinous and transverse processes of each named point

B) INCORRECT:

Flexion with sidebending toward and rotation away from the tender point is the appropriate counterstrain position for treating anterior thoracic tender points AT7–AT12. A useful mnemonic for remembering the correct treatment of AT7–AT12 is F STRA: flexed, sidebent toward, and rotated away.

C) INCORRECT:

Flexion of the upper torso with sidebending and rotation away from the tender point is the appropriate counterstrain position for treating posterior rib tender points PR2–PR10. A useful mnemonic for remembering the correct treatment of PR2–PR10 is F SARA: flexed, sidebent away, and rotated away.

D) INCORRECT:

Extension with sidebending and rotation away from the tender point is the appropriate counterstrain position for treating tender points located at the posterior thoracic levels on the spinous processes. A useful mnemonic for remembering the correct treatment of PT1–PT12 on the spinous processes is E SARA: extended, sidebent away, and rotated away. This mnemonic also applies to the treatment of the posterior cervical tender points (except PC1 midline and PC3 midline).

E) INCORRECT:

Flexion with sidebending and rotation toward the tender point is the appropriate counterstrain position for treating anterior rib tender points AR1–AR10. A useful mnemonic for remembering the correct treatment of AR1–AR10 is F STRT: flexed, sidebent toward, and rotated toward.
questions.hint: This patient has a posterior thoracic tender point located at the right transverse process of the T4 vertebra (i.e., PT4).
